chapterOverview: Chapter 1 of Chemistry class 10 explores the fundamental concepts of chemical reactions and equations. It introduces the different types of chemical reactions, such as combination reactions, decomposition reactions, displacement reactions, and redox reactions. The chapter also covers the balancing of chemical equations, the concept of oxidation and reduction, and the role of catalysts in chemical reactions.

content.example: A process in which one or more substances are converted into new substances with different chemical and physical properties
The substances present at the beginning of a chemical reaction
The substances formed as a result of a chemical reaction
A reaction in which two or more substances combine to form a new compound
A reaction in which a compound breaks down into simpler substances
A reaction in which an element displaces another element from a compound
A reaction involving both oxidation (loss of electrons) and reduction (gain of electrons)
A symbolic representation of a chemical reaction, showing the reactants and products
An equation in which the number of atoms of each element is equal on both sides
The principle that states that mass is neither created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction
The process in which a substance loses electrons or gains oxygen
The process in which a substance gains electrons or loses oxygen
A reaction involving both oxidation and reduction processes
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed in the process
Biological catalysts that facilitate chemical reactions in living organisms

chapterOverview: Chapter 2 of Chemistry class 10 delves into the concepts of acids, bases, and salts. It explores the properties and behavior of acids and bases, their classification, and their role in various chemical reactions. The chapter also covers the pH scale, indicators, and the importance of acids, bases, and salts in everyday life.

content.example: A substance that donates hydrogen ions (H+) or protons
A substance that accepts hydrogen ions (H+) or donates hydroxide ions (OH-)
A scale used to measure the acidity or basicity of a solution

topics.title: Chemical Properties of Acids and Bases

content.example: Properties exhibited by acids, such as sour taste, ability to turn blue litmus paper red, and ability to react with metals to produce hydrogen gas
Properties exhibited by bases, such as bitter taste, ability to turn red litmus paper blue, and ability to feel slippery
A chemical reaction between an acid and a base to form a salt and water
Acids that ionize completely in water and produce a high concentration of hydrogen ions
Acids that only partially ionize in water and produce a low concentration of hydrogen ions
Bases that dissociate completely in water and produce a high concentration of hydroxide ions
Bases that only partially dissociate in water and produce a low concentration of hydroxide ions

topics.title: Importance of pH in Everyday Life

content.example: Substances that change color depending on the pH of the solution

Medications that neutralize excess stomach acid
The use of lime (calcium carbonate) to neutralize acidic soil
A compound formed by the reaction of an acid with a base, characterized by an ionic bond
Various applications of salts, such as in food preservation, water treatment, and manufacturing processes

chapterOverview: Chapter 3 of Chemistry class 10 explores the properties, occurrence, and uses of metals and non-metals. It discusses the physical and chemical properties of metals, including their malleability, ductility, conductivity, and reactivity. The chapter also covers the differences between metals and non-metals, their occurrence in nature, and their significance in various industries.

content.example: An element characterized by its luster, malleability, ductility, and conductivity
Properties exhibited by metals, such as metallic luster, high thermal and electrical conductivity, malleability, and ductility
Reactivity of metals, such as their ability to form positive ions by losing electrons
An element that lacks metallic properties, such as luster, malleability, and conductivity
Properties exhibited by non-metals, such as dull appearance, low thermal and electrical conductivity, brittleness, and low density
Reactivity of non-metals, such as their ability to gain electrons to form negative ions
Naturally occurring minerals that contain metal compounds in sufficient amounts to make their extraction economically viable
Various methods employed to extract metals from their ores, such as roasting, reduction, and electrolysis

topics.title: Physical and Chemical Properties of Metals and Non-metals

content.example: A detailed comparison of the physical and chemical properties of metals and non-metals, including their melting and boiling points, reaction with acids, and reaction with oxygen
Various applications of metals in industries, such as iron in construction, aluminum in aircraft, and copper in electrical wiring
Uses of non-metals, such as carbon in the form of graphite in pencils and sulfur in matches

chapterOverview: Chapter 4 of Chemistry class 10 focuses on the properties, bonding, and reactions of carbon compounds. It explores the unique characteristics of carbon, its ability to form a variety of compounds, and the importance of carbon compounds in our daily lives. The chapter also covers the nomenclature of organic compounds and the concept of functional groups.

topics.title: Introduction to Carbon and its Compounds

content.example: A versatile element that forms the basis of organic chemistry due to its ability to form stable covalent bonds with other carbon atoms and various other elements
Compounds containing carbon atoms bonded to hydrogen atoms, along with other elements such as oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur, and halogens
Compounds composed of carbon and hydrogen atoms, such as alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes

topics.title: Properties and Bonding of Carbon Compounds

chapterOverview: Chapter 5 of Chemistry class 10 introduces the concept of the periodic table and the organization of elements based on their properties. It explores the historical development of the periodic table, the modern periodic law, and the significance of periodicity in understanding the properties and trends of elements. The chapter also covers the classification of elements into periods and groups, the arrangement of elements based on atomic number, and the periodic trends in atomic size, valency, and metallic and non-metallic character.

content.example: A tabular arrangement of elements based on their atomic numbers, electronic configurations, and chemical properties
The first periodic table developed by Dmitri Mendeleev in 1869, based on increasing atomic masses and periodic repetition of properties
The statement that the properties of elements are periodic functions of their atomic numbers
Horizontal rows in the periodic table that represent the energy levels or shells of atoms
Vertical columns in the periodic table that have elements with similar properties
Elements in groups 1, 2, and 13-18 of the periodic table that exhibit a wide range of physical and chemical properties
Elements in groups 3-12 of the periodic table that have partially filled d orbitals and show variable oxidation states

The combining capacity of an atom, which is determined by the number of valence electrons
The tendency of an element to exhibit metallic properties, which generally decreases across a period and increases down a group
The tendency of an element to exhibit non-metallic properties, which generally increases across a period and decreases down a group
The ability of an atom to attract shared electrons towards itself in a covalent bond
